unnormalised: The aroma of ripening mangoes hung heavy in the air around Ratnagiri, a scent young Rohan had always associated with the promise of a good harvest. His grandfather, Dada ji, however, was worried. Tiny beetles, unseen to the casual observer, were decimating the young fruit, a blight threatening their livelihood. Dada ji, like many farmers in the Konkan region, relied heavily on pesticides.
normalised: The aroma of ripening mangoes hung heavy in the air around Ratnagiri, a scent young Rohan had always associated with the promise of a good harvest. His grandfather, Dada ji, however, was worried. Tiny beetles, unseen to the casual observer, were decimating the young fruit, a blight threatening their livelihood. Dada ji, like many farmers in the Konkan region, relied heavily on pesticides.

unnormalised: I remember summer vacations spent shadowing Dada ji, watching him carefully mix the pesticide solution, the air pungent with its chemical tang. He’d explain, “Beta, these pests are relentless. Without these, our mangoes will be lost.” He used to purchase "Malathon" from the local Krishak Seva Kendra, always haggling for the best price. Last year it cost him Rs. 1200 for a 5-liter can. The yield increased, of course, but at what cost? The well water, once crystal clear, had started to taste… different.
normalised: I remember summer vacations spent shadowing Dada ji, watching him carefully mix the pesticide solution, the air pungent with its chemical tang. He'd explain, "Beta, these pests are relentless. Without these, our mangoes will be lost." He used to purchase "Malathon" from the local Krishak Seva Kendra, always haggling for the best price. Last year it cost him rupees one thousand two hundred for a five liter can. The yield increased, of course, but at what cost? The well water, once crystal clear, had started to taste… different.

unnormalised: Dr. Patil from the Regional Agricultural Research Station in Dapoli often held workshops, cautioning farmers about overuse. He'd explain about integrated pest management (IPM) techniques, introducing beneficial insects and crop rotation. But Dada ji, entrenched in his ways, found these methods slow and uncertain compared to the immediate impact of a pesticide spray. He even proudly showed me his sprayer, covering his 2 acres of land (roughly 87,120 sq ft) in a matter of hours.
normalised: Doctor Patil from the Regional Agricultural Research Station in Dapoli often held workshops, cautioning farmers about overuse. But Dada ji, entrenched in his ways, found these methods slow and uncertain compared to the immediate impact of a pesticide spray. He even proudly showed me his sprayer, covering his two acres of land (roughly eighty seven thousand, one hundred and twenty square feet) in a matter of hours.

unnormalised: The problem, as I later understood studying agriculture at Punjab Agricultural University, wasn't just the overuse of pesticides, but also the lack of awareness about their proper handling and long-term effects. Stories of farmers in Vidarbha suffering from pesticide poisoning were a grim reminder of the dangers.

unnormalised: Now, years later, having returned to Ratnagiri, I try to convince Dada ji to adopt more sustainable practices. We are slowly transitioning to organic farming in a small section of the orchard. It’s a daunting task, fighting not only the pests but also deeply ingrained habits. The initial yield from our organic patch was significantly lower, disheartening him.
normalised: Now, years later, having returned to Ratnagiri, I try to convince Dada ji to adopt more sustainable practices. We are slowly transitioning to organic farming in a small section of the orchard. It's a daunting task, fighting not only the pests but also deeply ingrained habits. The initial yield from our organic patch was significantly lower, disheartening him.

unnormalised: We introduced neem-based pesticides, sourced from a local supplier in Chiplun. It's a slow battle, convincing him that a healthy ecosystem, buzzing with life, is a more reliable safeguard than a quick fix from a bottle. The taste of organically grown mangoes, however, seems to be slowly changing his mind. The journey is long, but the sweetness of success, when it arrives, will be all the more rewarding, preserving both the mangoes and the land for generations to come. And maybe, just maybe, the well water will taste like it used to again.
